section.title: &name-icinga; and &name-idoutils; Quickstart on FreeBSD
section.para: This guide is intended to provide you with simple instructions on how to install &name-icinga; from source (code) and have it monitoring your local machine within 30 minutes.
No advanced installation options are discussed here - just the basics that will work for most of the users who want to get started.
This guide will give you examples for installation on &name-freebsd; 8.1-RELEASE. Thanks to "ScotchTape" for the adapted instructions.
Later distributions of &name-freebsd; may inherit from these examples.
If you follow these instructions, here's what you'll end up with:

listitem.para: &name-icinga; and the plugins will be installed underneath &url-icinga-base;
&name-icinga; will be configured to monitor a few aspects of your local system (CPU load, disk usage, etc.)
The &name-icinga; classic web interface will be accessible at http://localhost/icinga/ or http://yourdomain.com/icinga
a database being filled using the &name-idoutils;

section.para: During portions of the installation you'll need to have root access to your machine.
Make sure you've installed the following packages on your system before continuing.

At one time or another you will likely use SNMP based checks so it might be a good idea to install the required packages now. Otherwise the plugins will not be compiled and are not available when you need them.
If you want to use SSL-encryption : it is already installed.

note.para: SSL has to be activated on all idomod clients, otherwise you will lose data!!!

section.para: If you want to use Oracle as an RDBMS then we are sorry. Unfortunately it isn't that easy with &name-freebsd;.
You can install the packages from the ports or you take older packages (have a look at the &name-freebsd; quickstart quide
You can install these ports by running the following commands (as root) but it is recommended to use portupgrade or portmaster instead:

section.para: Run the &name-icinga; configure script. You will get help by using the --help flag.

important.para: Appending CPPFLAGS=-I/usr/local/include is important for the &name-idoutils; and the broker modul respectively.

section.para: Compile the &name-icinga; source code. There is a separate option for &name-idoutils; (make idoutils) if you just want to recompile this module. To see possible option just call "make".

Install binaries, init script, sample config files and set permissions on the external command directory. #> gmake install #> gmake install-init #> gmake install-config #> gmake install-commandmode #> gmake install-idoutils or shorter #> make fullinstall
The Icinga-API will be installed during "make install" so if you are required to install it manually please try: #> make install-apiThis will be mandatory for Icinga Web.
Don't start &name-icinga; yet - there's still more that needs to be done...
Sample configuration files have been installed using #> gmake install-configinto &url-icinga-base;/etc/. You'll need to make just one change before you proceed...

Edit the &url-icinga-base;/etc/objects/contacts.cfg config file with your favourite editor and change the email address associated with the icingaadmin contact definition to the address you'd like to use for receiving alerts.
section.programlisting: #> cd &url-icinga-base;/etc #> mv idomod.cfg-sample idomod.cfg #> mv ido2db.cfg-sample ido2db.cfg

para.emphasis: Install and configure the Classic Web Interface

section.para: &name-icinga; ships with the Classic Web Interface ("the CGIs") which can be installed via
section.programlisting: #> cd /path/to/icinga-src #> make cgis #> make install-cgis #> make install-html
section.para: If you are interested in the new &name-icinga; Web, please refer to Install &name-icinga; Web Interface.
Install the Icinga Classic web config file in the Apache conf.d directory.

note.para: There is currently a bug in &name-icinga; Makefile which directly prevents this make command, please edit Makefile file in &name-icinga; source directory and change the line $(INSTALL) -D -m 644 sample-config/httpd.conf $(DESTDIR)$(HTTPD_CONF)/icinga.conf to $(INSTALL) -m 644 sample-config/httpd.conf $(DESTDIR)$(HTTPD_CONF)/icinga.conf

section.para: Create an icingaadmin account for logging into the &name-icinga; classic web interface. If you want to change it later, use the same command. Remember the password you assign to this account - you'll need it later.

para.emphasis: Compile and Install the Nagios-/Perl Plugins

section.para: Extract the &name-nagios; plugins source code tarball.
Compile and install the plugins by changing install directory to &url-icinga-base;

note.para: There is a port for the plugins but it will install them in a different directory. You can set certain variables to tweak its make but you still have to copy some things manually later on.

Add &name-icinga; to the list of system services and have it automatically start when the system boots (make sure you have installed the init script before).
Verify the sample &name-icinga; configuration files.
If there are no errors, start &name-icinga;.

para.emphasis: Login to the Classic Web Interface

section.para: You should now be able to access the &name-icinga; classic web interface at the URL below. You'll be prompted for the username ( icingaadmin) and password you specified earlier.

Click on the "Service Detail" navbar link to see details of what's being monitored on your local machine. It will take a few minutes for &name-icinga; to check all the services associated with your machine.
Make sure your system's firewall rules are configured to allow access to the web server if you want to access the &name-icinga; classic interface remotely.
Setting up your mail transfer agent (MTA) like exim, sendmail or postfix to allow &name-icinga; sending notification emails won't be explained here.
Please refer to the &name-nagioswiki; for more resources.
Congratulations! You successfully installed &name-icinga;. Your journey into monitoring has just begun.
You'll no doubt want to monitor more than just your local machine, so check out the chapter on "Getting Started" about "Monitoring ..."
